_exec_summary.SummaryText:
THE ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND EMERGENCY ACTION POLICIES AT THIS FACILITY.  This facility complies with the Wisconsin Comm 43 for ammonia storage, and it is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to contact the BEAVER DAM Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency.
                                                                                                                                                                                         A DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED.  The facility is a farm cooperative.  The primary activity at this fertilizer facility is the storage, handling and mixing of fertilizers for distribution to local farmers. The 18,000 gallon storage tank that was reported in the initial RMP was dismantled and removed during the spring of 2004.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored,  and used for manufacturing of 10-34-0 and starter grades liquid fertilizer.  The maximum stored quantity of anhydrous ammonia is 130,000 pounds stored in one 30,000 gallon rail car.  The maximum fill level of each tank is 85% of the total tank capacity.
                                                                                                                                                                                     Liquid fertilizer  is manufactured by combining anhydrous ammonia, super phosphoric acid, and water in a converter reactor.  The super phosphoric acid is delivered in insulated rail cars.  The super phosphoric acid is transferred to the reactor via a flexable hose to the reactor tank.  The anhydrous ammonia is delivered by a high pressure rail cars.
                                                                                                                                                                                   Liquid anhydrous ammonia is  pumped from the storage tank, thro

ugh a meter and then through a heat exchanger where the liquid anhydrous ammonia is vaporized,  After the heat exchanger, the anhydrous ammonia is mixed with the water and phosphoric acid, which is pumped from the phosphoric acid rail car to the reactor.  The anhydrous ammonia and phoshoric acid react to form ammonium phosphates and heat.  The ammonium phosphates exit the reactor and enter a holding pool where they mix with water to form an ammonium phosphate solution (i.e., 10-34-0). 
                                                                                                                                                                                   Situated above the holding pool is a cooling tower woith a fan that pulls air up the tower off of the holding pool.  The ammonium phosphate solution is pumped to the top of the cooling tower where it flows down packing (i.e., Pall Rings) back down to the holding pool.  While falling down the packing, the water evaporates and cools the solution.
                                                                                                                                                                                   Some of the ammonium phosphate solution in the holding pool is pumped out to the anhydrous ammonia heat exchanger.  The warm ammonium phosphate solution is used to vaporize the anhydrous ammonia liquid from the anhydrous ammonia tank. The ammonium phosphorate solution, which is cooled by the anhydrous ammonia vaporization, flows back to the holding pool and some of the solution flows to a storage tank.
                                                                                                                                                                                     THE WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS.  Per the EPA requirements, we performed a worst case release scenerio, and reviewed alternative release scenerios for a release of anhydrous ammonia from our storage t

ank system at this site.  The information ws used to perform an off-site consequence analysis for both situations.  Descriptions of the worst-case and alternative release scenerios, and the results of the off-site consequence analyses for both, are included in Section 2 of this document. 
                                                                                                                                                                                     THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGARAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS.  This facility complies with EPA's accidental prevention rule and all applicable state and local codes and regulations.  The ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with Wisconsin Comm 43.
                                                                                                                                                                                    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY.  We have never had an accident involving this chemical that caused deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.
                                                                                                                                                                                     THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM.  In the event of an emergency involving the ammonia system. It is our policy to notify the BEAVER DAM FIRE DEPARTMENT and request that they repond to the emergency.  We have discussed our policies with the fire department and we periodically provide informational sessions.  

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY.  None.
